children.subject: If I’m correct, I’m like 99% sure that 120 is no longer a prerequisite for 106A. It still is listed as one but for all intents and purposes 120 material doesn’t show up in 106A
I took EE120 with Math 54 as my only preparation and did fine!
Thank you so much, this was all extremely helpful and will definitely make my decision a lot easier!!

Hi, 106A TA here! Can confirm 120 is not a prereq for 106A, but that it will be useful knowledge to have in 106B if you decide to take that. The 120 prereq on 106A exists for some weird bureaucratic reason that we can't really get rid of. The only real prereqs are linear algebra and some knowledge of Python or C++ for labs. 

From my understanding, a friend of mine found 120 extremely boring after having taken ME 132. Since it sounds like you don't have too much time left for classes, 120 might not be the best use of time. 

As a former 16B Lab TA, I'll also note that I think you'll probably be okay taking 16B, but the lab portion could very well possibly throw you for a loop if you're not comfortable building a debugging circuits. I'm unsure how 16B labs will work this coming semester (formerly they were optional but now everything is remote and on fire so who knows). As a student, I didn't find 16A to be particularly valuable after taking Math 54 and having a little knowledge of circuits from physics.

history.content:
Hi, I'm a rising senior in Mechanical Engineering and I've been increasingly interested in EECS throughout college (and thinking about a possible graduate degree in EECS). I'm planning on taking a few EECS courses my senior year and had some questions. First, I'm interested in taking EE120 and EE C106A; 120 has EE16A/B listed as prereqs and C106A has 120 as a prereq. I haven't taken the 16 series but I am familiar with circuit design, linear algebra, Python, a bit of machine learning, dynamic systems and feedback having taken Math 54/110, CS61A, ME 132 (dynamic systems) and ME 100 (electronics for the internet of things), though none of these were heavily lab-based (ME 100 in Spring 2020 sadly had to cancel the project). My questions are:

  • If I enroll in EE120, will I be out of my depth since I did not take the 16 series? Or is my background a sufficient enough substitute?
  • Is it a viable option for me to skip EE16A and take 16B, if I decide to do so? I was also thinking about watching the lecture recordings from a previous 16A semester to ensure I'm up to speed, even though I understand I'll be missing the lab component of the course, and homeworks, exams, etc. 
  • EE120 is pretty similar to ME132, some of the overlapping topics being LTI systems, transfer functions, frequency response, stability analysis, etc. If I decide not to take EE120 and take EE C106A (which EE120 is a prereq for), will I be out of my depth then? I have no problem reinforcing knowledge but I want to be wary about wasting time/taking a class that is too similar to ME132, but I'm not really able to gauge this.

Thank you!!
history.subject: Questions about EECS courses and prereqs from interested MechE student
